intro: Dalechampia bidentata, commonly known as the two-toothed dalechampia, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family, which includes plants known for their unique floral structures and milky sap. The plant is characterized by its palmately lobed leaves and clusters of small, inconspicuous flowers. It typically grows in wetlands and along stream banks, thriving in moist, well-drained soils. Its botanical features make it an important species for ecological studies and wetland conservation efforts.
